soc.message

Class SOCLocalizedStrings

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.message.SOCMessage
      • soc.message.SOCMessageTemplateMs
        • soc.message.SOCLocalizedStrings
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, SOCMessageFromUnauthClient, SOCMessageMulti

    public class SOCLocalizedStrings
extends SOCMessageTemplateMs
implements SOCMessageFromUnauthClient
    Message from server with i18n localization strings for certain item types such as game options or scenarios (TYPE_GAMEOPT or TYPE_SCENARIO), or request from client to get localized strings for specific keys of those certain item types. Is not requested by or sent to clients with locale en_US: Strings in that locale are already hardcoded in game classes for debugging.

    This message is always about one string type. The meaning of the keys and their strings may differ per string type. For example, keys for TYPE_SCENARIO are the same as those in SOCScenario and the server sends two strings per scenario, its short and long description.

    Normally sent from the server when client needs all keys or some keys for a type; see type constant javadocs. For example: When joining a game with a scenario, the client needs strings for that scenario. When creating a new game, the client needs strings for all scenarios in order to read about them and maybe choose one. The server's message includes the string type such as TYPE_SCENARIO, the flags field, and then each key and its string(s) as described above.

    Client can send this message to ask for localized strings for one or more specific (or use flag to request all) scenarios or gameopts, and/or for any ones added/changed in server versions newer than the client. The client's request includes the string type such as TYPE_SCENARIO, the flags field, and then any keys for which it wants localized strings (or an empty list if message also sets FLAG_REQ_ALL to request all items). The server's response is as described above, including all keys requested by the client. If a key isn't known at the server, in the response that key will be followed by MARKER_KEY_UNKNOWN instead of by its string(s).

    The first element of SOCMessageTemplateMs.getParams() is a string type such as TYPE_GAMEOPT or TYPE_SCENARIO. This is followed by the integer flag field (hex string) which is removed from the list at the receiving end's parser. The rest of getParams() is organized according to the type; see type constant javadocs. Receiving end automatically translates SOCMessage.EMPTYSTR elements to "".

    Max Length: When sending a long list, watch for the 65535-character limit mentioned at Connection.MAX_MESSAGE_SIZE_UTF8. Remember that limit is against the strings' UTF-8 encoding, not the internal encoding used with String.length(). If unsure, you can test length of the final message string with code like: 

    
   final String msg = new SOCLocalizedStrings(...).toCmd();
   final int len = msg.getBytes("utf-8").length;
   if (len > Connection.MAX_MESSAGE_SIZE_UTF8)
   {
       ....
   }

    Robot clients don't need to know about or handle this message type, because they don't have a locale.

    Introduced in 2.0.00; check client version against SOCStringManager.VERSION_FOR_I18N.

    Since:
    2.0.00
    Author:
    Jeremy D Monin <jeremy@nand.net>
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Field Detail

      • TYPE_GAMEOPT

        public static final java.lang.String TYPE_GAMEOPT
        Game Option localized names, for SOCGameOption: "O". After the string type at element 0, SOCMessageTemplateMs.getParams() contents are pairs of strings, each of which is a game option keyname and its localized name or "".
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • TYPE_SCENARIO

        public static final java.lang.String TYPE_SCENARIO
        Game Scenario localized names and descriptions, for SOCScenario: "S".

        From Client:

        SOCMessageTemplateMs.getParams() is a list of scenario keys (sc.key field) for which the client is requesting localized strings, or an empty list with FLAG_REQ_ALL to get updated strings for all scenarios.

        A client with a different version than server might instead send SOCScenarioInfo to ask for all scenarios' details and localized strings.

        From Server:

        After the string type at element 0, SOCMessageTemplateMs.getParams() contents are triples of strings, each of which is a game scenario keyname, localized name, and optional localized long description or "". As with any string type, an unknown keyname is a pair of strings here (not a triple): keyname, MARKER_KEY_UNKNOWN.

        If the client has requested specific scenario keynames for this type, the server replies with all known localized strings for those items. Items without localized strings will not be included in the reply. If none of the items are localized, server replies with an empty list with the FLAG_SENT_ALL flag.

        If the client has requested all scenarios (FLAG_REQ_ALL), server responds with a list including all localized scenarios in SOCServerScenario.getAllKnownScenarioKeynames() and the FLAG_SENT_ALL flag.

        When client sends a SOCJoinGame request, if that game has a scenario and the client hasn't yet been sent the scenario's info or localized strings, server may respond with SOCScenarioInfo or SOCLocalizedStrings for the scenario before it sends SOCJoinGameAuth.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • FLAG_TYPE_UNKNOWN

        public static final int FLAG_TYPE_UNKNOWN
        "Type is unknown" flag, for server's response when it doesn't recognize the string type requested by the client.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • FLAG_REQ_ALL

        public static final int FLAG_REQ_ALL
        "Request all" flag, for client to request all items of a requested type. This flag is sent with an empty string list. Not all string types support this flag.
        See Also:
        FLAG_SENT_ALL, Constant Field Values

      • FLAG_SENT_ALL

        public static final int FLAG_SENT_ALL
        "Sent all of them" flag, for server's response when it has sent all known items of the string type requested by the client. The client should not request any further items of that string type.

        This flag can also be sent when no known items are available for a recognized string type; the server will send an empty list with this flag set.

        See Also:
        FLAG_REQ_ALL, Constant Field Values

      • MARKER_KEY_UNKNOWN

        public static final java.lang.String MARKER_KEY_UNKNOWN
        "Key is unknown" marker token, for server's response when it doesn't have a localized string for the key requested by the client.

        For known SOCGameOptions and SOCScenarios, client should use the fallback text it has from the item's initializer. If the game option / scenario was unknown to the client, instead of SOCLocalizedStrings server would send a SOCGameOptionInfo / SOCScenarioInfo with those fallback texts.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Constructor Detail

      • SOCLocalizedStrings

        public SOCLocalizedStrings(java.lang.String type,
                           int flags,
                           java.lang.String str)
                    throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                           java.lang.NullPointerException
        Client-side request constructor, for a single string key.

        Before v2.4.50, a static toCmd(..) method was called by the client.

        Parameters:
        type - String type such as TYPE_SCENARIO; must pass SOCMessage.isSingleLineAndSafe(String).
        flags - Any flags such as FLAG_SENT_ALL, or 0
        str - String key being requested, with type-specific meaning; see type constant javadocs. Must pass isSingleLineAndSafe(String, true): SOCMessage.sep2 characters are allowed, but SOCMessage.sep are not. If any string starts with MARKER_PREFIX, it must be a recognized marker (like MARKER_KEY_UNKNOWN) declared in this class.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If type or (if not empty) str fails SOCMessage.isSingleLineAndSafe(String).
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if str is null
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • SOCLocalizedStrings

        public SOCLocalizedStrings(java.lang.String type,
                           int flags,
                           java.util.List<java.lang.String> strs)
                    throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Server-side constructor.
        Parameters:
        type - String type such as TYPE_SCENARIO; must pass SOCMessage.isSingleLineAndSafe(String). This constructor will prepend type to the strs list.
        flags - Any flags such as FLAG_SENT_ALL, or 0
        strs - the list of strings, organized in a type-specific way; see type constant javadocs. Each element must pass isSingleLineAndSafe(String, true): SOCMessage.sep2 characters are allowed, but SOCMessage.sep are not.

        The list may be empty or null. Since this constructor builds an object and not a network message command, will not replace empty or null elements with SOCMessage.EMPTYSTR. The constructor will prepend type to the strs list, creating it if null.

        If any string starts with MARKER_PREFIX, it must be a recognized marker (like MARKER_KEY_UNKNOWN) declared in this class.

        Max Length: See class javadoc for combined max length of list's strings.

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If type or any element of strs fails SOCMessage.isSingleLineAndSafe(String).

      • toCmd

        public java.lang.String toCmd()
        Build the command string; used at server side. Empty or null elements will be built as SOCMessage.EMPTYSTR. At the receiver, parseDataStr(List) will automatically replace EMPTYSTR with "". See SOCLocalizedStrings(String, int, List) for field/parameter details.
        Overrides:
        toCmd in class SOCMessageTemplateMs
        Returns:
        the command String

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Build and return a human-readable form of the message:
        "SOCLocalizedStrings:type=" + getType() + "|flags=0x" + hex(flags) + |strs=str1|str2|str3|...

        Null string elements are shown as "(null)". If the string list is empty, builds "(strs empty)" instead.

        Overrides:
        toString in class SOCMessageTemplateMs
        Returns:
        a human-readable form of the message
        See Also:
        SOCMessageTemplateMs.toString(List, String[])
